facts.text: Chicago Fire Football Club was founded on October 8, 1997.
The Chicago Fire won the MLS Cup and the U.S. Open Cup in their first season in 1998.
The Chicago Fire have won the U.S. Open Cup four times: in 1998, 2000, 2003, and 2006.
The Chicago Fire won the MLS Supporters' Shield in 2003.
Joe Mansueto purchased the Chicago Fire in 2019.
The Chicago Fire returned to play their home games at Soldier Field in the 2020 MLS season.
The Chicago Fire were originally based at Soldier Field from 1997 to 2006 before moving to SeatGeek Stadium from 2006 to 2019.
Notable U.S. internationals who have played for the Chicago Fire include Chris Armas, Carlos Bocanegra, and DaMarcus Beasley.
The Chicago Sting, a former soccer team in Chicago, won the Soccer Bowl in 1981 and 1984.
The Chicago Fire was founded in 1997 at Navy Pier on the anniversary of the Great Fire.
In their first competitive year, 1998, the Chicago Fire won both the MLS Cup and the U.S. Open Cup.
Bob Bradley was the first head coach of the Chicago Fire.
The Chicago Fire won the 2000 U.S. Open Cup by defeating the Miami Fusion.
Bob Bradley left the Chicago Fire in 2002 to lead the MetroStars.
Dave Sarachan was chosen to replace Bob Bradley as head coach of the Chicago Fire in 2002.
The Chicago Fire won the Supporters' Shield and the 2003 U.S. Open Cup.
Piotr Nowak retired from playing and took a position in the front office after the 2003 season.
The Chicago Fire missed the league playoffs for the first time in their history in 2004.
The Chicago Fire moved into Toyota Park, their new stadium in Bridgeview, in 2006.
The Chicago Fire won the U.S. Open Cup in 2006.
Cuauhtémoc Blanco was signed to a Designated Player contract by the Chicago Fire on April 3, 2007.
Juan Carlos Osorio was named the third head coach of the Chicago Fire in 2007.
On September 6, 2007, Andell Holdings, controlled by Andrew Hauptman, acquired AEG's interest in the Chicago Fire Soccer Club for an estimated purchase price upwards of $35 million.
The Chicago Fire Soccer Club has not won a major trophy since being bought by Andrew Hauptman.
Juan Carlos Osorio resigned as manager of the Chicago Fire on December 10, 2007, and was named manager of the New York Red Bulls eight days later.
After Juan Carlos Osorio's resignation, the Chicago Fire were compensated by the New York Red Bulls with cash and draft picks due to tampering charges filed by Andrew Hauptman.
Frank Klopas was named Technical Director of the Chicago Fire on January 17, 2008.
Denis Hamlett was appointed manager of the Chicago Fire in 2008.
Brian McBride signed with the Chicago Fire on a free transfer in July 2008.
The Chicago Fire advanced past the New England Revolution in the playoffs for the first time in four seasons in 2008.
The Chicago Fire lost to Real Salt Lake in the 2009 season's semi-final on penalties after 120 scoreless minutes.
Denis Hamlett was dismissed as manager of the Chicago Fire shortly after their 2009 season ended.
Carlos de los Cobos was hired as head coach of the Chicago Fire leading up to the 2010 season.
The Chicago Fire failed to qualify for the playoffs in 2010 for only the second time in club history.
Brian McBride and club original C.J. Brown retired at the end of the 2010 season.
Carlos de los Cobos was let go as head coach of the Chicago Fire on May 30, 2011.
Frank Klopas was named interim head coach of the Chicago Fire in 2011 and was given the permanent manager job on November 3, 2011.
The Chicago Fire qualified for the U.S. Open Cup Final but lost at Seattle in 2011.
Chris Rolfe was named the Fire's MVP in 2012 after scoring eight goals and providing 12 assists in 21 games.
The Chicago Fire achieved their best record since 2000 in 2012 with a 17–11–6 record.
The Chicago Fire lost their first-round MLS Cup playoff match against the Houston Dynamo on October 31, 2012, with a score of 2–1.
The Chicago Fire missed the playoffs for three out of four years leading up to 2013.
On October 31, 2013, Frank Yallop was named the new head coach and director of soccer for the Chicago Fire.
Mike Magee became the first Chicago Fire player to win the MLS MVP Award on December 5, 2013.
C.J. Brown and Clint Mathis were added as assistant coaches to the Chicago Fire's coaching staff under Frank Yallop.
Brian McBride was added as an assistant coach to the Chicago Fire in May 2014 for a short-term assignment.
The Chicago Fire suffered their worst competitive defeat in club history with a 6-0 loss to Seattle Sounders FC in the semifinals of the 2014 Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup on August 13.
The Chicago Fire set a record for most draws in an MLS season in 2014 with 18 draws.
David Accam, Shaun Maloney, and Kennedy Igboananike were signed as Designated Players by the Chicago Fire in 2015.
The Chicago Fire began the 2015 season with an 0–3–0 record for the first time in club history.
Shaun Maloney was transferred from the Chicago Fire to Hull City citing personal reasons in 2015.
Frank Yallop was parted ways with by the Chicago Fire on September 20, 2015, after a 1-0 home defeat to Orlando City SC.
Nelson Rodríguez was named the new general manager of the Chicago Fire following Frank Yallop's departure in 2015.
The Chicago Fire finished the 2015 season with zero road wins (0–12–5) for the first time in the club's history.
The Chicago Fire recorded twenty losses in the 2015 season, the highest in the club's history.
Veljko Paunovic, former coach of the Serbian U-20 side that won the 2015 FIFA U-20 World Cup, was named the new head coach of the Chicago Fire on November 24, 2015.
Bastian Schweinsteiger's move from Manchester United to Chicago Fire was completed on March 29, 2017.
Joe Mansueto, the founder of Morningstar, Inc., became the sole owner of Chicago Fire on September 13, 2019, after purchasing the majority share.
The Chicago Fire announced their return to Soldier Field for the 2020 MLS season on October 8, 2019.
Bastian Schweinsteiger announced his retirement on October 8, 2019, the same day Chicago Fire announced their return to Soldier Field.
The Chicago Fire traded captain Dax McCarty to expansion side Nashville SC on November 4, 2019.
Chicago Fire President and general manager Nelson Rodríguez fired head coach Veljko Paunovic and his staff on November 14, 2019.
The Chicago Fire announced a rebrand on November 21, 2019, changing their franchise colors to red, blue, and gold, their name to Chicago Fire FC, and introducing a new logo.
Raphael Wicky was named as the new head coach of Chicago Fire in late December 2019 by the new Sporting Director Georg Heitz.
The Chicago Fire signed Ignacio Aliseda from Defensa and Gaston Gimenez from Vélez Sarsfield to open their 2020 campaign.
Robert Beric, signed from Saint-Étienne, scored in his debut for the Chicago Fire in a match against Seattle Sounders FC, which ended in a 2-1 defeat.
The Chicago Fire's official primary colors are red, flag blue, deep blue, and white.
The original logo of the Chicago Fire, used from 1997 to 2019, was derived from the Cross of Saint Florian.
Nike originally intended for the team to be named the Chicago Rhythm, featuring a turquoise, black, and green color scheme and a cobra logo.
The names "Chicago Blues" and "Chicago Wind" were considered before deciding on the Chicago Fire.
The original Fire jerseys were chosen for their resemblance to a Chicago fireman's coat and featured broad horizontal stripes across the torso and sleeves.
The Fire's jersey maintained an all-red shirt with a white horizontal chest stripe through changes in equipment sponsor until 2012 when the white stripe was exchanged for a blue stripe.
The Chicago Fire's third shirts have often been yellow, originally to honor the Chicago Sting and later for the expired partnership with Morelia.
The Flag of Chicago is favored by fans and often seen at the stadium, reflecting the club and its fans' frequent use of symbols of Chicago as a show of civic pride.
The Chicago Fire Football Club underwent its first major rebranding on November 21, 2019, ahead of their move back to Soldier Field.
The rebranded crest of Chicago Fire FC introduced in 2019 was called the "Fire Crown" and used dark blue, red, and gold as its main colors.
The Chicago Fire FC's rebranding in 2019 received an overwhelmingly negative response from fans.
Chicago Fire FC unveiled a new crest in the middle of the 2021 season, designed by Matthew Wolff, with a full embrace beginning in 2022.
Chicago Fire FC played its home games at SeatGeek Stadium from 2006 until the end of the 2019 season.
SeatGeek Stadium, the home of Chicago Fire FC from 2006 to 2019, was originally named Toyota Park and opened on June 11, 2006.
The Chicago Fire FC returned to Soldier Field in 2020 after reaching a deal to leave SeatGeek Stadium for a payment of $65.5 million.
Chicago Fire FC owner Joe Mansueto announced plans for a new, privately funded soccer-specific stadium along the Chicago River on June 3, 2025.
The Chicago Fire played 1 U.S. Open Cup game at Forest View Park in Arlington Heights, Illinois in 2000.
The Chicago Fire played 1 U.S. Open Cup game at Milwaukee Sports Complex in Franklin, Wisconsin in 2001.
The Chicago Fire played 1 U.S. Open Cup game at McCully Field in Wheaton, Illinois in 2001.
The Chicago Fire played 2 U.S. Open Cup Qualifying games at Shea Stadium in Peoria, Illinois in 2008 and 2011.
Section 8 is the name of the standing area occupied by supporters and ultras groups at Chicago Fire matches, originally named after the corresponding section at Soldier Field.
Section 8 Chicago, the Independent Supporters' Association for the Chicago Fire, oversees the activities of numerous supporters groups.
Sector Latino was moved to Section 137 at the Chicago Fire's stadium following discussions between the ISA and the Chicago Fire Front Office.
The Section 8 Chicago ISA is a registered 501(c)7 non-profit organization.
The official mascot of the Chicago Fire is Sparky, an anthropomorphic Dalmatian dog.
The Chicago Fire and New England Revolution have met in the MLS Cup Playoffs 8 times from 2000 to 2009, with each team winning 4 times.
St. Louis City SC's entry into the MLS in 2023 sparked a rivalry with the Chicago Fire due to the historic rivalry between St. Louis and Chicago.
WGN Sports became a regional television rightsholder for Chicago Fire matches starting with the 2020 season.
Tyler Terens and Tony Meola were announced as part of the Chicago Fire television broadcast team in April 2021.
Arlo White was expected to call several Chicago Fire games after his debut was postponed in 2020 due to the pandemic.
Starting in 2023, Chicago Fire games were broadcast almost exclusively on Apple TV due to a rights deal, with exceptions for certain national linear television broadcast partners.
Spanish-language radio station WRTO has broadcast Chicago Fire matches since 2017.
On April 26, 2023, the Chicago Fire announced a deal with Cumulus Media to carry matches on English language radio on WLS 890 AM.
The "Ring of Fire" was established by the Chicago Fire Soccer Club in 2003 to honor individuals who have significantly contributed to the club's success.
Ante Razov, the club's all-time leading scorer, was inducted into the Chicago Fire's Ring of Fire Hall of Fame on October 3, 2015.
Zach Thornton was announced to be inducted into the Ring of Fire in 2024, with the ceremony scheduled for April 27 at Soldier Field.
Frank Klopas served as the Chief Operating Officer (General Manager) of Chicago Fire from 2008 to 2011.
Who served the longest continuous tenure as Director of Player Personnel for Chicago Fire from 1998 to 2023? Denis Hamlett (1998–2007)
In what year did Chicago Fire win the MLS Team Fair Play Award? 2009
How many times did Chicago Fire win the MLS Wooden Spoon, and in which years? Twice, in 2015 and 2016
Which individual served as Director of Player Personnel for Chicago Fire in both 2000 and 2020? Frank Klopas
Who was appointed as Director of Player Personnel for Chicago Fire starting in 2024? Paulo Nagamura
What does the Golden Boot award signify for Chicago Fire? The team leader in goals during the regular season games only
Lionel Messi's arrival at Chicago Fire drove MLS record ticket revenue for the club in 2023.
The Chicago Fire reacquired forward Chris Rolfe, as announced on their official website.
Houston defeated Chicago Fire 2–1 in a match detailed on the Chicago Fire's official website.
The Chicago Fire traded for Bakary Soumaré on May 23, 2013.
Mike Magee was traded to Chicago Fire in exchange for Robbie Rogers, as confirmed on May 25, 2013.
Chicago Fire defender Arne Friedrich announced his retirement on June 23, 2013.
Frank Klopas and Javier Leon stepped down from their positions at Chicago Fire on October 30, 2013.
Frank Yallop was named the new Head Coach and Director of Soccer for Chicago Fire on October 31, 2013.
Mike Magee was voted the 2013 Volkswagen MLS Most Valuable Player on December 5, 2013.
Chicago Fire FC won the MLS Cup in 1998.
The Chicago Fire FC is planning to move to a new stadium in 2028.
Frank Klopas served as the interim coach for Chicago Fire FC in 2021 before taking over as head coach again in 2023.
Chicago Fire FC won the Supporters' Shield in 2003.
Tampa Bay Mutiny, Miami Fusion, and Chivas USA are all defunct MLS teams.
LA Galaxy won the MLS Cup in 2022.
The MLS Cup was not held in 2000 and 2001.
New England Revolution won the Supporters' Shield in 2002.
Real Salt Lake won the MLS Cup in 2009.
Which team won the MLS Cup in 1998?
Chicago Fire
Which team did not hold the MLS Cup in 2000 and 2001?
Which team won the MLS Cup in 2023?
Los Angeles FC
Which team won the Supporters' Shield in 2000?
Kansas City Wizards
Which team won the Supporters' Shield in 2021?
New England Revolution
How many times did LA Galaxy win the MLS Cup from 1996 to 2024?
9 times
Which team won the Supporters' Shield in 2017?
Toronto FC
Which team won the Supporters' Shield in 2023?
FC Cincinnati
Bethlehem Steel won the U.S. Open Cup three times in a row from 1915 to 1917.
Fall River F.C. won the U.S. Open Cup three times in a row from 1930 to 1932.
Stix, Baer and Fuller won the U.S. Open Cup three times in a row from 1933 to 1935.
Philadelphia Ukrainians won the U.S. Open Cup three times in a row from 1960 to 1962.
New York Greek American Atlas won the U.S. Open Cup three times in a row from 1967 to 1969.
Maccabi Los Angeles won the U.S. Open Cup four times, with their victories coming in 1973, 1975, 1977, and 1978.
Seattle Sounders FC won the U.S. Open Cup four times in six years, with their victories coming in 2009, 2010, 2011, and 2014.
The U.S. Open Cup was not held in 2020 and 2021.
Houston Dynamo won the U.S. Open Cup in both 2018 and 2023.
The Chicago soccer team won the MLS Cup in which year?
How many U.S. Open Cup titles has the Chicago soccer team won?
Who was the shirt sponsor of the Chicago soccer team from 2019 to 2022?
Motorola
Who served as the head coach of the Chicago soccer team from November 24, 2015, to November 13, 2019?
Veljko Paunović
In what year did the Chicago soccer team first have Best Buy as their shirt sponsor?
Who was the president of the Chicago soccer team from 2018 to 2021?
Nelson Rodríguez
Which player, listed with the Chicago soccer team, is on loan from Cádiz as of the last update?
Rominigue Kouamé
Gregg Berhalter became the head coach of the Chicago soccer team in which year?
Logan Pause played for the Chicago Fire from 2003 to 2014, making a total of 317 appearances.
Ante Razov is the top goalscorer in Chicago Fire's history with 76 MLS goals.
Nemanja Nikolić was the top goalscorer for Chicago Fire in 2019 with 13 goals.
Robert Berić was the top goalscorer for Chicago Fire in 2020 with 12 goals.
In 2021, Robert Berić and Luka Stojanović were the top goalscorers for Chicago Fire, each scoring 8 goals.
Jhon Durán was the top goalscorer for Chicago Fire in 2022 with 8 goals.
Maren Haile-Selassie was the top goalscorer for Chicago Fire in 2023 with 6 goals.
Nemanja Nikolić won the Golden Boot for Chicago Fire in 2017 with 24 goals.
Mike Magee won the Golden Boot for Chicago Fire in 2013 with 15 goals.
Chicago Fire finished 8th in the conference and 17th overall in the 2019 MLS season.
Chicago Fire's average attendance in 2023 was 18,170.
Bastian Schweinsteiger won the Defender of the Year for Chicago Fire in both 2018 and 2019.
